subject: Re: Getting @Ignore reported?
msgSnippet: This is a known issue in Ant: https://issues.apache.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=43969 Unfortunately they don t seem eager to fix it because there is a lot of
messageBody:
This is a known issue in Ant:

https://issues.apache.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=43969

Unfortunately they don't seem eager to fix it because there is a lot of
dependency on that XML output for other projects, and they are afraid to break
it.

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Pigneri, Rocco" <rpigneri@...> wrote:
>
> Dear Bob,
>
>
>
> You need to use both the @Test and the @Ignore annotations in order to
> get the behavior that you want. Without the @Test annotation, the test
> runner does not consider the function a test and ignores it.
>
>
>
> Hope that helps,
>
>
>
> Rocco
>
>
>
> From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of
> resendes
> Sent: Thursday, February 12, 2009 1:41 PM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: [junit] Getting @Ignore reported?
>
>
>
> I'm new to JUnit, so I'm probably missing something obvious, but does
> anyone know how to get @Ignore occurrences to get reported?
>
> For example, given the following source code:
>
> T.java: the implementation class to be tested
>
==============================================
> public class T {
> public static int positive() { return 1; }
> public static int negative() { return -1; }
> public static int zero() { return 0; }
> }
>
> TTest.java: the test class
> ==========================
> import org.junit.Test;
> import org.junit.Ignore;
> import static org.junit.Assert.*;
>
> public class TTest {
> @Test
> public void positive() {
> assertTrue( "Positive", (T.positive() > 0) );
> }
> @Test
> public void testNegative() {
> assertTrue( "Negative", (T.negative() < 0) );
> }
> @Ignore("Not ready, yet")
> public void testZero() {
> assertTrue( "Zero", (T.zero() == 0) );
> }
> }
>
> I get the following output from ant:
>
> $ ant unittest
> Buildfile: build.xml
>
> compile:
>
> compile-tests:
> [javac] Compiling 1 source file to test-classes
>
> unittest:
> [junit] Running TTest
> [junit] Tests run: 2, Failures: 0, Errors: 0, Time elapsed: 0.083 sec
> [junitreport] Processing TESTS-TestSuites.xml to /tmp/null1495231817
> [junitreport] Loading stylesheet
> jar:file:/usr/share/ant/lib/ant-junit.jar!/org/apache/tools/ant/taskdefs
> /optional/junit/xsl/junit-frames.xsl
> [junitreport] Transform time: 682ms
> [junitreport] Deleting: /tmp/null1495231817
>
> BUILD SUCCESSFUL
> Total time: 2 seconds
>
> ... and the following output from JUnit itself ...
>
> $ java -ea -cp /usr/share/java/junit4.jar:classes:test-classes
> org.junit.runner.JUnitCore TTest
> JUnit version 4.3.1
> ..
> Time: 0.011
>
> OK (2 tests)
>
> In both cases, above (and the generated HTML reports from ant),
> there's no notification that we ignored any tests. What am I missing,
> here? The JavaDoc for @Ignore seemed to imply that this type of info
> should be reported (see http://junit.org/apidocs/org/junit/Ignore.html):
> "... Native JUnit 4 test runners should report the number of ignored
> tests along with the number of tests that ran and the number of tests
> that failed."
>
> My goal was to use @Ignore to "intelligently comment" out some tests.
> For example, something like:
>
> @Ignore ("Tests bug #4321 when fixed")
>
> Ideally, I'd like to see that tests were ignored and be able to
> extract the annotation string to why they were ignored.
>
> Bob
>
>
>
>
>
> [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
>
